GLOBALSETTINGS.Comments: Modelo de Dados do sistema PLANdora - www.plandora.org

DATATYPE.Description: A very small integer. The signed range is -128 to 127. The unsigned range is 0 to 255.
A small integer. The signed range is -32768 to 32767. The unsigned range is 0 to 65535.
A medium-size integer. The signed range is -8388608 to 8388607. The unsigned range is 0 to 16777215.
A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.
A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.
A large integer. The signed range is -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807. The unsigned range is 0 to 18446744073709551615.
A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38.
A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38.

A normal-size (double-precision) floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Allowable values are -1.7976931348623157E+308 to -2.2250738585072014E-308, 0, and 2.2250738585072014E-308 to 1.7976931348623157E+308.
This is a synonym for DOUBLE.
This is a synonym for DOUBLE.
An unpacked floating-point number. Cannot be unsigned. Behaves like a CHAR column.
This is a synonym for DECIMAL.
A date. The supported range is \a1000-01-01\a to \a9999-12-31\a.
A date and time combination. The supported range is \a1000-01-01 00:00:00\a to \a9999-12-31 23:59:59\a.
A timestamp. The range is \a1970-01-01 00:00:00\a to sometime in the year 2037. The length can be 14 (or missing), 12, 10, 8, 6, 4, or 2 representing YYYYMMDDHHMMSS, ... , YYYYMMDD, ... , YY formats.
A time. The range is \a-838:59:59\a to \a838:59:59\a.
A year in 2- or 4-digit format (default is 4-digit).

A fixed-length string (1 to 255 characters) that is always right-padded with spaces to the specified length when stored. values are sorted and compared in case-insensitive fashion according to the default character set unless the BINARY keyword is given.
A variable-length string (1 to 255 characters). Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion unless the BINARY keyword is given.
This is a synonym for CHAR(1).
This is a synonym for CHAR(1).
A column maximum length of 255 (2^8 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 65535 (2^16 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 16777215 (2^24 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 4294967295 (2^32 - 1) characters. Values are sorted and compared in case-sensitive fashion.
A column maximum length of 255 (2^8 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 65535 (2^16 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 16777215 (2^24 - 1) characters.
A column maximum length of 4294967295 (2^32 - 1) characters.
An enumeration. A string object that can have only one value, chosen from the list of values.
A set. A string object that can have zero or more values, each of which must be chosen from the list of values.
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype
Geographic Datatype

TABLE.Comments: This table contain all company areas of system. It can be used to categorize an user and can be used into reports.
This table contain a list of all categories of system. A category could be used to give more qualification for the requirements and tasks for a specific project.

COLUMN.Comments: id of project related to the category
if \a1\a the category is applicable to the requirement, if \a0\a, it is a task category

TABLE.Comments:
This table contain all customer of all projects. Each customer ID should be into the user table, to respect the architecture hierarchy 
where a Customer entity IS A User entity. 
Besides, the customr entity contain a number of attributes of the relationship between the specific customer and the project (exemple: enable status, pre approving permission, etc). Because a Resource and Leader entities are automatically a Customer entity, all this attibutes defines into the customer table will be inherited by Resource and Leader entities.

COLUMN.Comments: if it is \a1\a the current customer is disabled to perform actions for the related project
if it is \a1\a the current customer is allowed to view the technical comments that was written by resources into the tasks.
if it is \a1\a all the requirements opened by this customer for the related project will be turn in tasks automatically without leader approving.

TABLE.Comments: This table contain all company departments of system. It can be used to categorize an user and can be used into reports.
This table contain all company functions of system. It can be used to categorize an user and can be used into reports.
This table contain the IDs of all project leaders. Each leader ID should be into the resource table, to respect the architecture hierarchy where a Leader entity IS A Resource entity.

This table contain the sequence used by system to increment the ids of all tables. The architecture of system was desing to avoid using features of specific data bases. A \Asequence\A feature and \Aauto-increment ID\A feature are available in many commercial data bases, but each data base has a specific rule to create and increment the sequence, then into PLANdora the control os \AID sequence\A is into the business rules of system and the table p_sequence store the next ID available.
This entity is a abstraction of the main planning entities of system, i.e, Task, Requirement and Project. \nThis \Asuper-entity\A contain the common fields of all planning entities.

COLUMN.Comments: Description of the entity (task, requirement, project, etc)
Entity final date (when it isn\at null the entity was excluded)

TABLE.Comments: This table contain all projects of system.

COLUMN.Comments: ID of parent project (used to create a hierarchy of projects for Gantt Chart, KPI and Reports purposes)

TABLE.Comments: This table contain the life-cycle of a project. Each state transition of project is stored here.

This table contain all status of project. Each status is related to a numeric constant used into the system to define the status. This constant is following: 1 - Project Opened ; 2 - Project on-Hold ; 3 - Project Aborted/Closed

This table contain all Report or KPI records of system. Each Report or KPI contain a SQL statement. A Report use the SQL statement to populate data into the Jasper report layout. In the other hand the system timer use the SQL statement of KPI record to get a indicator value from data base and set the new value into the report_result table.

COLUMN.Comments: If it is a KPI, define the BSC perspective, otherwise is NULL
SQL statement that implement the metric business rule.
Execution time of metric (hour that timer should wake up to run the SQL)
Project id related with the metric
Final date of metric. If NULL the metric is alive, otherwise, contain the date/time of exclusion.
If the current record is a KPI this field is null, otherwise, contain the path of Jasper file used by report engine.

TABLE.Comments: This table contain the values (metrics) generated by timer when it wake up and run a KPI\as SQL clausule.

COLUMN.Comments: KPI value (generated after the timer execution)

TABLE.Comments: This table contain all requirements of system (bugs, support requests, system requirement, etc).

COLUMN.Comments: User id related to the requirement (customer)
It is 1 if current requirement demands the customer acceptance to be closed, otherwise, it is 0
Number of times that requirement was reopened

TABLE.Comments: Each requirement has the own life cycle, and this table contain the information about the historical occurrence of the requirement.

COLUMN.Comments: requirement status key related to the history occurrence
creation date of current history occurrence
user id related to the history occurremce

TABLE.Comments: This table contain a list of all status of the requirement. Each status is related to a numeric constant used into the system to define the status. This constant is following: 1 - Waiting Approve ; 100 - Planned ; 200 - Canceled ; 201 - Closed ; 202 - Refused ; 300 - In-Progress

COLUMN.Comments: Numeric constant of requirement status state machine. 1=Waiting Approve; 202=Refuse; 201=Closed; 200=Canceled; 100=Planned; 300=in-Progress

TABLE.Comments:
This table contain all resources of all project. Each resource ID should be into the customer table, to respect the architecture hierarchy 
where a Resource entity IS A Customer entity. 
Besides, the resource entity contain a number of attributes of the relationship between the specific resource and the project (exemple: cost, capacity, etc). Because a Leader entity is automatically a Resource entity, all this attibutes defines into the resource table will be inherited by Leader entity.

COLUMN.Comments: If it is \a1\a the resource could set tasks for him self
The cost of one hour of this resource into the related project
If is is \a1\a the resource could view into the \Aresource task\A form the name of the customer that made the request.
The number of minutes (capacity) allocated to this resource to work into the project

TABLE.Comments: This table contain the allocation of resource for a specific task. Contain the general information about the status, task date and duration. However, there are another table (resource_task_alloct) that contain the time values along the time day by day. For example, if the resource_task contain a task that should be completed in 12 hours, then there are two related rows in resource_task_alloc with value = 8 and 4.

COLUMN.Comments: Estimated Date to start the task by resource
Estimated time (in minutes) to finish the task
Current status of task (for a specific resource)
boolean field that define if current task/resource is under customer approval.

TABLE.Comments: This table contain the allocation of human resources for a specific task. An allocation is a quantity of minutes used by resource to work in the task.

COLUMN.Comments: Sequence used to order the task slots (It is used into Gantt Chart for scheduling purposes)
Time value allocated into the slot (in minutes)

TABLE.Comments: This table contain only one record. It is the ID of root user and is always \A3\A and it is alwayed related to the project \A0\A. The project \A0\A it is the root project.
This table contain a list of all tasks of system. A task represent a work event performed by the resources of project.

COLUMN.Comments: Project ID related to the task
Requirement ID related to the task
Category ID related to the task
Parent Task ID. The parent task is used to join a group of tasks.
If it is 0 the current task is a common task, if it is 1 the task is a joinner task (used to join a group of tasks)

TABLE.Comments: Each task has the own life cycle, and this table contain the information about the historical occurrence of the task.

COLUMN.Comments: Project id related to the task
Estimated initial date to the conclusion of task (historical occurrence)
Id of user related to the history event

TABLE.Comments: This table contain all status of task. Each status is related to a numeric constant used into the system to define the status. This constant is following: 1 - Task Open ; 100 - Task Closed ; 101 - Task Canceled ; 20 - Task In ProgressI ; 50 - Task on-Hold

COLUMN.Comments: Numeric constant of \Atask status\A state machine. 1=Open; 100=Close; 101=Canceled; 20=in-Progress; 50=on-Hold

TABLE.Comments: This table contain all users of system, independently of project or role.

COLUMN.Comments: User name that should be used in login process
Representative color of user (used by Gantt Chart bars to identify a task assigned to user). It is a RGB hexadecimal pattern (ex: FF0000 = red, C2C2C2= gray, etc)
Country related to user used by system for i18n purposes (ex.: BR, US, etc)
Language related to user used by system for i18n purposes (ex.: pt, en, etc)

TABLE.Comments: This table contain the customized system preferences of users that selected options different from standard.

COLUMN.Comments: user id related to the preference option

TABLE.Comments: This table contain all assets of system. A asset is a component (software, hardware, etc) that is related to the requirement. It Is advisable that all requirements contain a list of affected assets. This relationship is useful to perform the rastreability through the requirements in order to perform analisys or to measure (for example) the impact of a change on the application.

COLUMN.Comments: The origin of asset: Configuration Item or a Repository Item
The category ID related to the asset. Each source should contain distinct categories
The project related to the asset. If NULL, the asset could be used in all projects.
Revision (or version) of File. It is useful in order to store the information about a file in a repository.
version of sofware related to the requirement
Company that made or commercialized the software
An identification of software into the escope of company that is using the PLANdora. For example: account number, \Apatrim\244nio\A or even the accounting number
An identification of software into the escope of company that is using the PLANdora. For example: account number, \Apatrim\244nio\A or even the accounting number

TABLE.Comments: This table contain the event generated by system. Some events of system could be stored into data base and used for audit purposes. The Logger Notification save the event information into this table as well. The event table contain the reference (username) to the user that has included the event but it doesn\at has any FK to user table.

COLUMN.Comments: Event type. Could be a mneumonic or some free string that could be used to group the events
Who create the event (username of user table)

TABLE.Comments: This table contain the notification os system. A notification is an alert that starts in a determined moment and send a customized message for a specific channel. The native channel implemented into the tool is: Email, Http and DBLog, but more channels could be extended through the framework of tool.

COLUMN.Comments: the class signature (package structure plus class name) that implement the channel of notification (email, http, or some customized implementation)
the SQL that contain the condition of notiication. In other words, if the SQL return some data from DB means that something should be sent by the notificator.
number of times that the notification engine will try to send the alert.
Date/time provisioned by system to send the next alert.
If null, the current alert is active. If the alert is disabled, this field contain the date/time of disabling action.
The minute that the notification should starts.
The haur that the notification should starts.

TABLE.Comments: This table contain the fields used by the channel of notification in order to provide the parameters used for notification engine. For example: the native email notification of tool contain knows how to send an e-mail but it need some information about that SMPT server, user, tittle, etc, that changes in each case. Thus, the records of this tables will be \Atranslated\A in customized fields of the notification GUI.

COLUMN.Comments: the unique name of the field (parameter) notification.
the value of parameter that will be used into the channel implementation
the user related to the history event

TABLE.Comments: This table contain represents an occurrence of an event iinto the project. The occurrence is a event that happend during the project and should be registered in order to keep the tracking of project history. The architecture point of view, the table occurrence is a super-class that can be extended to child classes that contain specific fields to store information of project occurrences.\nEach occorrunce could be linked with 0 or more records of planning table. Thus, an occurrence could be related to a group of requirements, tasks of projects.

COLUMN.Comments: The class that implements the specific behavior of the occurrence.
Name of occurrence. Could be used to quickly describe the occurrence record.
The id of occurrence status . Each occurrence sub-class define a list of status that is appliable for each kind of occurrence

The name of occurrence status related to the occurrence_status field. This field is mandatory if the occurrence_status was fulfiled. This field is redundant in order to be used into reports or queries.

QUERYRECORD.SQLText: CREATE TABLE P_SEQUENCE (Id BIGINT(9) NOT NULL, PRIMARY KEY PK_P_Sequence (Id));
